title: What If God Is Evil? | Stephen Law
description:
Stephen Law, professor of philosophy at Oxford, discusses his "evil god challenge" to theists: prove that God is not perfectly evil. That challenge, we will see, is surprisingly difficult to meet.

Stephen's paper outlining the evil-god challenge: https://www.jstor.org/stable/40927250

Mooney and Hendricks paper critiquing the challenge: https://academic.oup.com/analysis/advance-article-abstract/doi/10.1093/analys/anae049/8217397

title: Does Mind-Brain Harmony Point to God? | Graham Oppy vs. Brian Cutter
description:
Graham Oppy and Brian Cutter join me to debate philosophy's newest argument for God: the argument from psychophysical harmony. We talk about epistemic probability versus metaphysical possibility, the relevance of thought-experiments to determining possibility, whether mental states are identical to brain states, and what we ought to infer if we found John 3:16 in binary code in the digits of pi.

Cutter and Crummet's paper: https://philarchive.org/rec/CUTPHA

Previous interview with Oppy: https://youtu.be/DhEcsuWmSME

Previous interview with Cutter: https://youtu.be/KRkAtTm6VJo

title: Could the Universe Come from Nothing? | Daniel Linford
description:
Dr. Dan Linford and I discuss the causal principle, that everything that begins to exist has a cause. We look at William Lane Craig's oft-repeated three reasons for affirming the premise: something cannot come from nothing, if something could come from nothing, then anything and everything should come from nothing, and an inductive generalization supports the causal principle.

Linford's paper discussing neo-Russellian analyses of causation, "Without microphysical causation, not just anything can begin to exist just anywhere": https://link-springer-com.ezproxy-prd.bodleian.ox.ac.uk/article/10.1007/s13194-025-00683-z

title: The Multiverse Supports Belief in God | #47 Dr. Klaas Kraay
description:
Dr. Klaas Kraay explains that the multiverse, rather than serving as an alternative to God, actually supports belief in God by undermining two atheistic arguments: the problem of evil and the problem of no best world.

title: Best Objections to the Fine-Tuning Argument, Answered
description:
This video, titled with tongue in cheek, did not result from an 'official' survey of any kind. Instead, I asked my YouTube subscribers what they thought were the strongest objections to the fine-tuning argument. I discuss those objections in this video. Maybe they're the best ones, maybe not - but they are worth taking seriously, and they are ones that I have thought about myself for some time:

1. So What?
2. Normalizability
3. Principle of Indifference
4. Scientific Anti-Realism

My paper, 'Divine Psychology and Cosmic Fine-Tuning': https://www.cambridge.org/core/services/aop-cambridge-core/content/view/B137A39544971A6D275F48F52C2D2918/S0034412524000088a.pdf/divine-psychology-and-cosmic-fine-tuning.pdf

title: Could God Deceive Us? #evil #atheism #problemofevil
description: The 'divine deception' objection to skeptical theism, explained.

title: We’ve Solved the Problem of Evil | #13 Dr. Perry Hendricks
description:
Perry Hendricks, author of the recently published book Skeptical Theism, joins me to discuss one of the main theistic strategies for responding to the problem of evil, the problem of reconciling the evil and suffering in the world with the existence of an all-loving God. After outlining that response, Perry and I go through the four strongest objections to it: divine deception, Climenhaga's conundrum, equiprobability, and radical insensitivity.

Perry's book-length treatment of skeptical theism: https://www.amazon.com/Skeptical-Palgrave-Frontiers-Philosophy-Religion/dp/3031342704/ref=sr_1_1?crid=34QJGLLUZ4C7K&dib=eyJ2IjoiMSJ9.1Ca4y1xo2e_l58I_YoWhPybHkztRj3PVSXjcBIptfdvFgkp84JTL1_RCzPY0fADlntruIUwNURr_7WZfukkqZq7nBVFRsldbgCRtBNuIdcMayYKsSYdKOSSI2kCI1aGXkX3tmgwZBks5h7JC_SAOspYrlrbOfGvBy6ynOIBTZ8g8_eAi_cnMtMo3DmLFA3QjCRmYwDl0G1pdhYq6tAXWhQuE-89f0NaW7RbPAGMHS4Y.Hnn1_Cfgp2iTCpU1lYRyD5TYW7Ue1irxhl_kZFs38nY&dib_tag=se&keywords=skeptical+theism&qid=1734342090&sprefix=skeptical+t%2Caps%2C507&sr=8-1

The article from Brian what's-his-name: https://www.cambridge.org/core/journals/religious-studies/article/how-much-horrific-suffering-is-enough/79CC3B8958EF2B4C7E78AAA78ED0DD70

title: Contradiction in W. L. Craig on Canaanite Slaughter? #oldtestament #williamlanecraig
God Did Not Slaughter the Canaanites | #12 Dr. Randal Rauser
description:
Dr. Randal Rauser lays out the case against attempts to defend a literal interpretation of the biblical passages surrounding the slaughter of the Canaanites. We discuss William Lane Craig's (@drcraigvideos ) defense of those passages, the purported moral difference between slaughter and driving a people group from their homes, hyperbole in the Ancient Near East, and what a Christian is to do if they believe that a literal reading of the Canaanite conquest narratives cannot be correct. 

THE IMPORTANT LINKS

To read William Lane Craig's defense of the slaughter of the Canaanites: https://www.reasonablefaith.org/writings/question-answer/the-slaughter-of-the-canaanites-re-visited

To access Dr. Rouser's book: https://www.amazon.co.uk/Jesus-Loves-Canaanites-Biblical-Intuition/dp/1775046249/ref=sr_1_1?crid=2L68PQ9KI0BMU&dib=eyJ2IjoiMSJ9.42PtkKMzwiB3O0rq8Vt7iIPN0E8IaPErl-ukS9P1qwSius_t_2HI5aJuPdAR6Qrzx2CjywRl1M0B2rPS89ODsY8w_E7iGU8SsdA2KZRC6zPJ64u-bXAWFpJaoLzcFfOM8jlCvedpf0jNSbu-Ht6QAf53lQzKZF8xcqWza2UsYdTL-gNLECV8llhtDlShcKtd3tdNDQJcAkmhCh3oTIWbte0nV0X0DnDVVAwxuSM7efE.blGCaf-mjf7m8-_URKqv19bdUTiaKqETUpBJLboFwQY&dib_tag=se&keywords=randal+rauser&nsdOptOutParam=true&qid=1733636232&sprefix=randal+raus%2Caps%2C546&sr=8-1

To view Craig's dialogue with Alex O'Connor: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=WjsSHd23e0Q

title: Physics Points to God | #11 Rabbis Feder and Zimmer @PhysicsToGod
description:
Rabbis Elie Feder and Aaron Zimmer, cohosts of the 'Physics to God' podcast, join me to discuss their project in showing how physics provides strong evidence for the existence of God. We discuss several aspects of the fine-tuning argument - whether a deeper law of physics can remove fine-tuning, the Achilles' heel of the multiverse, and whether God is a simple or complex hypothesis.

Aaron and Elie's website: https://www.physicstogod.com/

Link to the Physics to God podcast: https://open.spotify.com/show/0lRFojBRYelxrLabzbPEDI

title: Is God a Simple or Complex Hypothesis? #richarddawkins #finetuningargument #god #atheism
description: Preview of upcoming discussion with rabbis Aaron Zimmer and Elie Feder.

title: Turning the Tables on Theists | #10 Dr. Richard Carrier
description:
Dr. Richard Carrier and I discuss his article, 'Ten Ways the World Would be Different if God Existed,' Carrier's case that we can turn ten theistic arguments on their head and use them to prove atheism. We naively thought we had time for all ten, but in 1.5 hours, we only discussed three - still, we had a substantive, spirited debate about the merits of theism and naturalism that I hope you'll enjoy.

Carrier's article: https://www.richardcarrier.info/archives/26502

Sinhababu's article, 'Electrons in Love': https://r.jordan.im/download/religion/DIVINE%20FINE-TUNING%20VS.%20ELECTRONS%20IN%20LOVE.pdf

title: Debating Richard Carrier (Briefly) #naturalism #evolution #theism
description: A preview of coming attractions.

title: Einstein was Wrong about Relativity | #9 Dr. Tim Maudlin
description: Dr. Tim Maudlin, professor of philosophy at NYU, joins me to discuss the difference between quantum and classical mechanics, that various "interpretations" of quantum mechanics, why Sean Carroll is wrong to suppose that the many-worlds interpretation is better than all the rest, what Einstein's theories of special and general relativity tell us about the nature of time, and how philosophy and science relate.

title: Does God Require Fine-Tuning? Round #2
description:
In this second installment of my interaction with questions and comments, I continue the debate over whether God would be just as fine-tuned as the universe that theists claim God is necessary to explain. I still think this objection to the fine-tuning argument fails, but at least I understand the other side of the argument now!
IMPORTANT LINKS

Part 1: https://youtu.be/12lSz6LaqzY

Calum...Miller's paper arguing that theism is a simple hypothesis: https://www.jstor.org/stable/26159841

Check out the podcast version of this channel: https://podcasters.spotify.com/pod/show/miles-k-donahue

title: The Universe Began to Exist | Luke Barnes
description:
Dr. Luke Barnes joins me to discuss whether empirical evidence indicates that the universe began to exist, and how theism and naturalism fare as explanations for the fine-tuning of the universe for intelligent life.

To purchase Barnes' book-length discussion of the fine-tuning argument: https://www.amazon.com/Fortunate-Universe-Finely-Tuned-Cosmos/dp/110874740X/ref=sr_1_1?crid=1L5B9MMUCV6D8&dib=eyJ2IjoiMSJ9.QsmHfg8HNjiU738BSD7vMd7ZuOPyhkopIIVN46Az2YiueYYVEE0gAs7hpEwS9Kz1XaCRSkanOovHzwLSgfqH0g.mlpuWYB6pSD9KbqLYLA5XRi-v8GaaI1bq_kMBF0kQlE&dib_tag=se&keywords=a+fortunate+universe&qid=1730023427&sprefix=a+fortunate+univers%2Caps%2C325&sr=8-1

To read Barnes' article on the fine-tuning argument: https://philarchive.org/archive/BARARL-3

title: God, Science, and the Multiverse | AAP Conference 2024
description: On October 18th, I spoke at the 2024 Australasian Association of Philosophy conference on the topic of God, science, and the multiverse. In particular, I aimed to see how recently proposed models of a theistic multiverse compared to scientific accounts of the multiverse. Are the two compatible or contradictory? I contend that although they conflict in a superficial way, they do not do so in any substantive sense.

title: Is God Just as Fine-Tuned as the Universe?
description: In the inaugural video for the newest segment of the channel, Questions and Comments, I add some thoughts on a recent back-and-forth I had with a commentor about whether God would have to be just as fine-tuned as the universe that He is called upon to explain - and if so, does that mean that theism is a bad explanation of the fine-tuning of the universe for intelligent life?

title: The Best Arguments For and Against God | Joe Schmid
description:
Joe Schmid joins me to discuss the best arguments for God's existence, and the best arguments against. We explored several nuances of the cosmological argument (for God) and the argument from gratuitous animal suffering (against God).

Joe's YouTube channel, Majesty of Reason, accessible here: https://www.youtube.com/@UCvWRKmcplBTYQS49AVGsLgw 

A list of Joe's publications: https://josephschmid.com/research/

title: Did God Create the Multiverse? | Ignatianum University, Cracow, Poland.
description: On September 24th, I (virtually) attended and spoke at my first professional philosophy conference, "Christian Philosophy Facing Naturalism," held at Ignatianum University in Cracow, Poland. My talk was titled, "Theistic Multiverses and the Fine-Tuning Argument." My aim was to examine philosopher Michael Rota's contention that even if a multiverse exists, we should still infer that a cosmic designer was responsible for the fine-tuning of the universe. I ultimately reject Rota's case for this provocative conclusion.

title: Debating One of Academia's Leading Atheists | Graham Oppy
description:
Dr. Graham Oppy, professor of philosophy at Monash University and author of the wide-ranging exploring of arguments for God's existence 'Arguing about Gods' published by Cambridge University Press, joins me to discuss the relationship between science and religion, morality and God's existence, the future of philosophy of religion, and what the point of philosophy is in the first place.

For Oppy's, 'The Best Argument Against God,' see: https://www.amazon.com/Best-Argument-against-Palgrave-Pivot/dp/1137354135/ref=sr_1_1?crid=28LZPCB3JZA3Q&dib=eyJ2IjoiMSJ9.toFvXU1uhjb4862-y2lINxfxpCIhx7WOYQ2u584XphyEl6FhAE6b6UXlXPAz1VZtP6nAh9RSQSzJ1ivBlyG3g1sRNb52YGyORq52RLpBr1m0JnljevX8pvD3OMno9pPAmYIxKXVY8y-2P30eeUU0lsMr9M634eHaX2vjMMo39SBziwwO0rEStxwWrS3uYopoHL0cYcDU1eo2gsXS8Xjags_HJtFao1VxeB_g_iBbPrw.h-GdXKkBCJtqwLzvJ8QTXduclUK_HHdnMpYb9U0A3Nk&dib_tag=se&keywords=the+best+argument+against+god&qid=1726960223&sprefix=the+best+argument+against+%2Caps%2C311&sr=8-1

For more information about Oppy and a list of his publications, see: https://research.monash.edu/en/persons/graham-oppy

title: NDEs are Proof of an Afterlife | #5 Dr. Max Baker-Hytch
description:
Dr. Max Baker-Hytch, tutor in philosophy at Oxford, joins me to discuss his recent published research on near-death experiences (NDEs) and their evidential significance, whether they provide reason to believe in an afterlife, and the strengths and weaknesses of natural explanations for these remarkable phenomena.

Max's publication on NDEs: https://www.academia.edu/123701615/Glimpses_into_the_Great_Beyond_On_the_Evidential_Value_of_Near_Death_Experiences

A compendium of Max's publications: https://oxford.academia.edu/MaxBakerHytch

title: Could Science Discover God? | #4 Dr. Hans Halvorson
description:
Hans Halvorson, professor of philosophy at Princeton, joins me to discuss the relationship between religion and science and whether a scientist could ever appeal to God to explain some aspect of the natural world. We also touch on what philosophy in general has to contribute to science, as well as the place of philosophy in the world at large.

For a list of Hans Halvorson's publications, see here: https://philpeople.org/profiles/hans-halvorson

title: The Kalam Cosmological Argument Fails | #3 Dr. Alex Malpass
description:
Alex Malpass, former lecturer in philosophy at the University of Bristol become software engineer, joins me to debate the kalam cosmological argument: the argument that because the universe began to exist, there must be a Creator that brought it into being. Malpass is one of the most articulate and careful critics of the argument, so it was a pleasure to discuss it with him.

"All the Time in the World," Alex's paper discussing the 'successive addition argument' against an infinite past: https://philpapers.org/rec/MALATT-2

A list of Alex's publications: https://philpeople.org/profiles/alex-malpass

Alex's blog with loads of good philosophical content: https://useofreason.wordpress.com/

00:00 - Introduction
05:41 - "Everything the begins to exist has a cause."
23:56 - "The universe began to exist."
24:23 - First philosophical argument for a beginning of the universe.
54:26 - Second philosophical argument for a beginning of the universe.
01:17:38 - "If the universe has a cause, then a transcendent, personal Creator exists."

title: The Five Ways...and Why They Fail
description:
I explain and assess Thomas Aquinas' (1225-1274) famous five-part case for the existence of God, concluding that although each argument fails as it was originally formulated, nevertheless there are modern descendants of these arguments that are worth exploring further. If you've ever wondered about a necessary being that grounds the necessity of all other necessary beings, well you're in luck, because imma tell you all about it.

B-ROLL FOOTAGE CREDITS

title: A Brand-New Fine-Tuning Argument for God | #2 Dr. Robin Collins
description:
I discuss a new kind of fine-tuning argument for God's existence with Dr. Robin Collins, professor of philosophy at Messiah University, one centered on the remarkable ability of human beings to discover the universe around us. Were the constants of physics altered in the smallest way, our capacity to understand the universe, our very ability to do science in the first place, would be remarkable diminished, if not irradicated entirely. Why, then, do the laws of physics take on these delicately balanced values that allow us to discover scientific truths? With Collins as my interlocutor, I take the chance to press objections that Neil Manson raised in our previous interview - philosophy in real time!

For more information about Robin, as well as a list of his publications, please see: https://www.messiah.edu/homepage/1662/robin_collins

title: Debating a Professor on the Fine-Tuning Argument for God | #1 Dr. Neil Manson
description:
In my first ever interview for this channel, I discuss and debate the fine-tuning argument with philosopher Neil Manson, a professor at the University of Mississippi. We discuss several lesser examined issues with the fine-tuning argument: how we could ever know what kind of universe God would likely create, theistic versus naturalistic multiverses, and whether, in the end, fine-tuning gives us any reason to think that God exists.

IMPORTANT LINKS

An online repository of Neil Manson's publications: https://philosophy.olemiss.edu/neil-a-manson/.

title: Is God the Ultimate Fictional Character?
description:
In this (very loosely connected) response to one interpretation of Jordan Peterson's views about religion, I examine the reasons for and against religious fictionalism, the proposal that religious discourse, far from being about an objective reality 'out there,' is actually just an exercise in fiction - but that doesn't mean we should abandon religion, because partaking in the fiction yields great benefits for our lives. So says fictionalism, anyway. I ultimately reject this view in favor of religious realism. And make some jokes along the way.

Quotation from Jordan Peterson in title is taken from "Douglas Murray and Jonathan Pageau", 33:24: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=4Modzh94MVw&t=0s

REFERENCED YOUTUBE VIDEOS

Alex O'Connor, "Deconstructing Jordan Peterson on Religion": https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=5-yQVlHo4JA&t=83s

Alex O'Connor and Jordan Peterson, "Navigating Belief, Skepticism, and the Afterlife": https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=T0KgLWQn5Ts&t=1307s

REFERENCED SCHOLARSHIP

Robin le Poidevin's book, Religious Fictionalism: https://www.amazon.co.uk/Religious-Fictionalism-Elements-Philosophy-Religion/dp/1108457479/ref=sr_1_1?crid=3TOZLCTLYGSQG&dib=eyJ2IjoiMSJ9.uf4Hyh9Z3fCK5qf8V4w8Qr5Bp2tW2WYJgXOLmQsPlDUDwqlqqlW8lpiahJ2K0yb4-WZlDOaYfU8F56IyMCqHqwbnYJtmxWIxecaf8IJu06syHEyFg7wd0HYakjX9rxY0Q1Y-0ONp0ubHiaJYUbgpxiQBM_nRoXenQCyGzW4KKxPXcQs5PMYWJ7a0dIGXAoyJ6LnE6IHapBo3pwTQANmHdu4OVRF_ClH9NFZQElwNRDA.5LXz7IGlD7xf-348sIS2aBCfsRK1XprjEkATXONkuQQ&dib_tag=se&keywords=religious+fictionalism&qid=1722979648&sprefix=religious+fictionalism%2Caps%2C90&sr=8-1

Cordry, "A critique of religious fictionalism": https://www.jstor.org/stable/25676923

Plantinga, "Is belief in God properly basic?": https://www.jstor.org/stable/2215239

title: Cosmic Fine-Tuning: God or a Multiverse?
description:
The fine-tuning argument is the claim that various features of the laws of physics are best explained by the hypothesis of a cosmic designer. I, first, explain what physicists mean by "fine-tuning" in this context, and second, explore four possible explanations for this remarkable scientific discovery: appeal to chance, a multiverse, an underlying theory of future physics, and a cosmic designer. Rather than arguing for any particular answer, I survey of few problems and prospects for each.

THE MOST IMPORTANT PAPER EVER WRITTEN ON FINE-TUNING

"Divine Psychology and Cosmic Fine-tuning," available for free at https://www.cambridge.org/core/journals/religious-studies/article/divine-psychology-and-cosmic-finetuning/B137A39544971A6D275F48F52C2D2918
